about.name: Yoran Nap
about.intro: Currently the product designer @storbie in Wellington, NZ. You can contact me at yoran.nap@gmail.com and connect with me on @linkedin
paragraphs: I started my journey back in 2014, messing around with Photoshop, designing album art for up-and-coming Soundcloud artists. I loved it and transitioned into part-time freelance work while studying Visual Communication at Yoobee School of Design in Christchurch back in 2017.

After graduating, I jumped into freelance work - designing a range of websites, branding identities, graphics and animations full-time for 2.5 years before joining the team at Storbie in Wellington. At Storbie, I have contributed to the redesign of storbie.com, created a virtual studio, helped re-define the brand, and led the product design of many new features among other projects.
Feel free to get in touch; I’m always keen for a chat!

projects.title: The Red Panda Project
projects.introduction: Bringing awareness to a flagship species through a digital experience.

sections.data: I wanted to create a purposeful, engaging and palatable digital experience to help tell the story of the Red Panda.
Less than 10,000 of these cute endangered animals are left to roam the bamboo bedded forests of the eastern Himalayas through to southwest China.

They’re best known for snacking on bamboo with their opposable thumbs and napping on high branches with dangling legs. All things that are not easy to do whilst being hunted for their fur and forced to the boundaries of their habitat.
/projects/red-panda/philippe-oursel-NuTeY7SV-D8-unsplash.jpg
sections.caption: Photo by Philippe Oursel on Unsplash

sections.data: I wanted to handle every aspect of this project; planning, research, illustration, design, coding and testing - all to challenge my skillsets.
The strategic approach

Simplicity, interactivity and playfulness were the key values driving the decisions for the project. With this, the information became more digestible and piqued the interest of the user. Since Red Pandas are playful, it made for a fun and intriguing creative direction.
/projects/red-panda/brainstorm.png
sections.caption: A mind map to brainstorm project connections

sections.data: The design approach

While researching I found Red Pandas are best known to be curious, innocent and playful. I felt illustrations would be the best way to embody these characteristics. I tried several different styles and approaches to incorporate this. The one I ended up with felt like the perfect balance between geometric simplicity and freehand fun, which made for a unique illustration style.
/projects/red-panda/concepts.png
sections.caption: Four illustration styles I explored

sections.data: My process for creating these illustrations was as followed:

data: Trace and adapt to create solid geometric shapes
Scan and recreate in Adobe Illustrator
Refine paths to make them more fluent and smooth
Add secondary shapes to add interest and dimension

sections.data: Using shades of red, orange and yellow created a nice analogous palette that stayed true to the colours of Red Panda fur. It reinforced simplicity and gave a unified feel.
/projects/red-panda/process.png
sections.caption: The illustration creation process

sections.data: Horizontal scroll

To make this project feel like it was telling a story chapter-by-chapter, and to create a point of difference, I wanted to incorporate a horizontal scroll. With this page-by-page approach, the information became more structured and purposeful.
I was hoping that requiring the user to click from page to page would also encourage engagement and interactivity, enhancing the overall experience.
Animation and interactivity
In an attempt to make the project more interesting and to add some WOW factor, I felt that animation was another key element to explore.

The initial zoom animation on page load instantly draws the user into the story they are about to experience. With each page-turn, content and illustrations smoothly guide the user from chapter to chapter, creating anticipation and excitement for what’s going to happen next.
/projects/red-panda/page-turn.gif
sections.caption: Demonstrating how horizontal scroll works

sections.data: Layout and typography
One way I was able to incorporate structure and simplicity was to stick with a fixed grid layout, making information organised and controlled without feeling rigid.
Combining a strong sans-serif with a crafty serif font, allowed for an interesting balance between serious and playful, further incorporating the project’s design ideology.
The process
Once I had established the brief, it was time to research. Spending a solid chunk of time studying similar projects allowed me to have a broad palette of options and ideas to mix and match.
Research sources included Behance, Pinterest, Wikipedia, and National Geographic, among many others.
Conceptualising

The next stage was spending time sketching, planning, wireframing and testing. This solidified the idea and concluded the direction for the rest of the project, as well as establishing the key points of uniqueness.
/projects/red-panda/wireframes.png
sections.caption: Exploring various layouts with simple wireframes

sections.data: Coding

I began coding this project on Wordpress due to its easy-to-use CMS, however, this created more code-clutter than it was worth. After some contemplation, I decided to learn and utilise Vue (a Javascript framework) - further challenging my front-end development skills.
Learning Vue was hugely beneficial. It not only elevated this project but has since helped improve some other projects of mine.
Technology

The website is built and statically generated with Vue, using GSAP for animation, JSON to store data, and Netlify for hosting. With a file directory size of under 800kb, it’s super lean and loads in mere milliseconds.
/projects/red-panda/code.jpg
sections.caption: A screenshot showing a glimpse of the project code

sections.data: Reflection

One of my key learnings from this project was gaining a better understanding of research techniques. On this project, I spent a lot more time than usual conceptualising, which I now see was hugely beneficial and will help elevate future projects.

The second skill that was incredibly useful to learn was front-end development. With this, I was able to bring the project to life and have an end-product showcasing my efforts and more importantly; bringing awareness to the Red Panda.
Next time

I would love to improve my sketching and drawing skills to create more textured, detailed and rich illustrations. I believe that strong illustrations have such a big impact on the uniqueness and feel of a project.

Secondly, this project took way too long to complete. I had other work I was juggling, but there’s no doubt there was fluff that could have been reduced to deliver the same project in a shorter timeframe.
Overall, this project has been great fun and I can’t wait to get my hands into the next one!

projects.title: Designing a Virtual Studio
projects.introduction: Boosting the internal team’s productivity and customer satisfaction with a virtual studio.

sections.data: One of my first projects after joining the Storbie team was to improve the quality of our customers’ websites visually and structurally - adding value and improving the performance of their websites.
We needed to do this quickly and effectively as we had a large influx of new customers wanting websites to support their businesses and community through the 2020 lockdown.

After some brainstorming, we decided that creating a library of graphics was the best way to approach the problem. These graphics would allow our customers to add visual interest to their website; supporting their content. These graphics needed to meet a few different criteria to be effective.
Original and copyright safe
We wanted our customers to use these graphics without restriction to avoid legal complications that could come with licensed graphics.  For this reason, we decided to design the graphics in-house.
Scalability

Our main customer industries included pharmacies, veterinaries and general retail. We needed the graphics to work in the context of their websites to effectively support their content. The graphics library needed to be adaptable and scalable, so we could add new graphics as we grew.
We decided to build this library in the form of icons rather than illustrations or photography. Since icons are vector-based we could easily manipulate colour, line thickness and background.
/projects/virtual-studio/all-icons.png
sections.caption: The full library of graphics

sections.data: Uniqueness

We needed the graphics to be dynamic and unique to each customer so that no two websites would look the same. To do this, we decided to inject the brand colours of the customers’ business directly into the icons.

Colour alone wasn’t going to be enough, so adding a background shape was another way we could add variety. The background shape could be filled with colour, be opaque or transparent. They could have a stroke, be a circle, be a square or anything in between. Adding these variables exponentially increased the possible visual outcomes, meaning we could create a perfectly unique combination for each customer.
/projects/virtual-studio/variations.png
sections.caption: A demonstration of some possible variations

sections.data: The process

Initially, all 107 icons were designed in Adobe Illustrator. Using global colours and, with a few tweaks, an experienced Illustrator user could export the library and upload them to a customer site in 10 to 15 minutes.

Customers were happy, their sites were more unique, and much quicker to build. This was great, but there was still room for improvement. We were bound to get hundreds of new customers in the coming months, and the team had to rely on me to export the graphics for each site. 10 to 15 minutes per site started to add up pretty quickly.
I ended up building a web application to solve this issue. The app needed to be user friendly and easy to use so that anyone in Storbie could export the graphics in under a minute.
/projects/virtual-studio/final.png
sections.caption: A screenshot of the virtual studio in action

sections.data: Conceptualising
We needed an MVP to validate the idea and to make sure it was worthwhile and effective. Using plain HTML, CSS, and Javascript, I built a prototype.

After validating the MVP, we thought there might be more elements that could benefit from this approach - like the generation of unique sidebar graphics, dividers and illustrations. To make this expansion, we needed to start working with a front-end framework to make life a bit easier as the project grew.
After refactoring the original code and injecting it into the Vue framework, we had a V1 of the virtual studio ready to roll and improve as we saw fit.
Additional use cases

A few months later, we made a few alterations to Storbie’s branding and needed to update the brand guidelines. Rather than creating a PDF that would get lost and altered with multiple versions, I decided to incorporate the brand guidelines into the Studio. This created a source of truth so that the guidelines could dynamically grow in one place.
/projects/virtual-studio/branding.png
sections.caption: Showcasing the branding page in the studio

sections.data: Another way we ended up using the Studio was to generate sidebar and divider graphics for our customers. I also coded a JSON editor within the Studio, allowing anyone on our team to create our technically complex content packs without dev knowledge.
Reflection

I am very happy with the result. This virtual studio has saved our team a tonne of time and significantly improved the visual direction of our customer websites. Learning to code with Vue and making the studio as dynamic and agile as we needed it to be was a big learning curve for me. However, it was so much fun to work on, and the end product is exactly what we needed. On to the next one!
